title: 3 Easy Ways to Uninstall App Updates on Android

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. Tap the app icon of a gear or swipe down from the top of your screen and tap the gear icon that appears in the Quick Panel. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Apps.
steps.content: Tap Apps . It's near the top of the Settings menu next to the icon of squares in a grid. This will display a list of all your downloaded and system apps. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the icon in the upper-right corner.
steps.content: Tap the icon in the upper-right corner. It's to the right of "Your Apps" and displays a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Tap the switch next to Show system apps to turn it on .
steps.content: Tap the switch next to Show system apps to turn it on . It's at the top of the drop-down menu and, as long as the switch is blue and pointing to the right, will display system apps that came with your phone.

steps.title: Tap an app.
steps.content: Tap an app. All the apps installed on your Android device are listed in alphabetical order. This will display the Application Info page. [4] X Research source You can only uninstall updates on certain apps on certain phones that came pre-installed on your Android device.

steps.title: Tap ⋮.
steps.content: Tap ⋮ . This three-dot menu icon is in the upper-right corner of the Application Info page. If you don't see this button in the upper-right corner, you cannot uninstall updates. Jump ahead to learn how to uninstall the app and install an unofficial older version of the app instead.

steps.title: Tap Uninstall updates.
steps.content: Tap Uninstall updates . You will see a popup asking if you want to uninstall updates for the app. [5] X Research source If you don't see this option, you won't be able to uninstall app updates. This usually happens with some Android system apps, such as the Camera app.

steps.title: Tap OK.
steps.content: Tap OK . It's in the lower-right corner of the popup. This will confirm that you want to uninstall updates before uninstalling them. [6] X Research source This will restore the version of the app that came with your phone. You will not be able to roll back to an earlier version of the app. Once you've rolled back an app, you probably want to open the Play Store and prevent your app from updating automatically .

steps.title: Download APK Installer.
steps.content: Download APK Installer. APK Installer is an app that installs APK files on your Android device. Use the following steps to download and install APK Installer: Open the Google Play Store . Type "APK Installer" in the search bar. Tap "APK Installer". Tap "Install".

steps.title: Download and run Droid Hardware Info.
steps.content: Download and run Droid Hardware Info. Before we get too far, you'll need to find out some important hardware specs about your Android phone so you can make sure we download the right version of the app. Use the following steps to download and install Droid Hardware Info Open the Google Play Store . Type "Droid Hardware Info" in the search bar. Tap Install below "Droid Hardware Info. Tap Open when it finishes installing.

steps.title: Take note of your phone's OS version and DPI.
steps.content: Take note of your phone's OS version and DPI. In the "Device" tab of Droid Hardware Info, note the version of Android you are running in the "OS Version" section and make note the DPI in the "Software Density" section below. The DPI has to do with your phone's screen size. It's a good idea to write these down so you don't forget.

steps.title: Tap the System tab on the Droid Hardware Info app.
steps.content: Tap the System tab on the Droid Hardware Info app. It's at the top of the app.

steps.title: Make note of your Android's CPU architecture.
steps.content: Make note of your Android's CPU architecture. Here you'll want to pay attention to two options, "CPU Architecture" and "Instruction Sets." From these two sections, you want to find out if your Android runs an ARM chipset or an x86 chipset as well as if it's a 32-bit chipset or a 64bit chipset. If either of these options mention 64 , there's a good bet it's the 64-bit version, if you don't see a 64 mentioned, it probably isn't. If your phone is 64-bits, you can run 32-bit apps without any problems as long as they are the same type (ARM vs. x86), but a 32-bit phone will not run 64-bit apps. The most common CPU in modern Android phones is arm64 .

steps.title: Uninstall the app you want to downgrade.
steps.content: Uninstall the app you want to downgrade. Before you install the older version of the app, you'll want to uninstall the app completely. You may want to take note of what version the app is currently so you can install the previous version. To uninstall any app: Open Settings app. Tap Apps & notifications (or Apps on Samsung Galaxy devices). Tap the app. Tap Force Stop . Tap Uninstall .

steps.title: Allow APK Installer to install apps from Unknown Sources.
steps.content: Allow APK Installer to install apps from Unknown Sources. Use the following steps to allow APK Installer to install apps from Unknown Sources. Open the Settings app. Tap Apps & notifications . Tap ⋮ in the upper-right corner. Tap Special Access Tap Install unknown apps Tap APK Installer Tap the toggle switch next to Allow from this source .

steps.title: Open https://www.apkmirror.com in a web browser.
steps.content: Open https://www.apkmirror.com in a web browser. Open your mobile browser and go to the official APK Mirror website.

steps.title: Tap the magnifying glass icon enter the name of the app.
steps.content: Tap the magnifying glass icon enter the name of the app. It's in the upper-right corner of the page. APK Mirror has a lot of current and older versions of many popular apps so look for the version you want to download. If you don't see the specific version you're looking for: Tap the Apps tab. Tap the app's title . Scroll down to All versions (listed newest to oldest).

steps.title: Tap next to the version you want to download.
steps.content: Tap next to the version you want to download. Tap the down-arrow icon on the right, next to the version of the app you want to download. This will take you to the download page.

steps.title: Tap SEE AVAILABLE APKS and tap the variant number of the version that fits your phone.
steps.content: Tap SEE AVAILABLE APKS and tap the variant number of the version that fits your phone. In the "Download" section, under the "Variant" column, tap the version that meets the specifications you noted earlier for your phone. If the version says "arm" then that's the 32-bit version, whereas "arm64" is the 64-bit version. If your phone is 64-bits, you can run 32-bit apps without any problems as long as they are the same type (ARM vs. x86), but a 32-bit phone will not run 64-bit apps. If there is no version that matches your DPI exactly, select the "nodpi" version, as that usually will fit all screen sizes.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap DOWNLOAD APK.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap DOWNLOAD APK . It's a button towards the bottom of the screen. Once the file downloads, you will be asked to open the folder or open the file. It's more effective to open the file in the My Files app. Tap OK if prompted with a disclaimer asking if you want to download this type of file.

steps.title: Open the "My Files" app.
steps.content: Open the "My Files" app. This is the default file manager app on Android devices. On most Android devices, this can be found in the Apps drawer. On some Android devices, this may be called "Files". On Samsung Galaxy devices, this can be found in the Samsung folder in the Apps Drawer.

steps.title: Open the "Downloads" folder.
steps.content: Open the "Downloads" folder. It's in the File Manager app. This displays all apps you have downloaded from the internet. Samsung Galaxy devices also have a folder called "Installation Files" specifically for APK files. You can find your APK files here or in the Downloads folder.

steps.title: Tap the APK file of the app you want to install.
steps.content: Tap the APK file of the app you want to install. All APK files have a file extension that ends with ".APK".

steps.title: Tap the APK Installer app and tap Always.
steps.content: Tap the APK Installer app and tap Always . The first time you open an APK file, you will be asked if you want to select a program to open the file with. Tap the APK Installer app icon and then tap Always at the bottom of the screen.

steps.title: Tap Install.
steps.content: Tap Install . It's in the lower-right corner of the installation screen. This will install the app. After the app installs, it will launch. The first time the app launches, it will ask to access different features on your phone. Tap "Allow" to let the app access the feature it is requesting.

steps.title: Download and run Droid Hardware Info.
steps.content: Download and run Droid Hardware Info. Before we get too far, you'll need to find out some important hardware specs about your Android phone so you can make sure we download the right version of the app. Use the following steps to download and install Droid Hardware Info Open the Google Play Store . Type "Droid Hardware Info" in the search bar. Tap Install below "Droid Hardware Info. Tap Open when it finishes installing.

steps.content: Take note of your phone's OS version and DPI. In the "Device" tab of Droid Hardware Info, note the version of Android you are running in the "OS Version" section and make note the DPI in the "Software Density" section below. The DPI has to do with your phone's screen size. It's a good idea to write these down so you don't forget.

steps.title: Tap the System tab on the Droid Hardware Info app.
steps.content: Tap the System tab on the Droid Hardware Info app. It's at the top of the app.

steps.title: Make note of your Android's CPU architecture.
steps.content: Make note of your Android's CPU architecture. Here you'll want to pay attention to two options: "CPU Architecture" and "Instruction Sets." From these two sections, you want to find out if your Android runs an ARM chipset or an x86 chipset and if it's a 32-bit chipset or a 64-bit chipset. If either of these options mentions 64 , there's a good bet it's the 64-bit version, if you don't see a 64 mentioned, it probably isn't. If your phone is 64-bits, you can run 32-bit apps without any problems as long as they are the same type (ARM vs. x86), but a 32-bit phone will not run 64-bit apps. The most common CPU in modern Android phones is arm64 .

steps.title: Uninstall the app you want to downgrade.
steps.content: Uninstall the app you want to downgrade. Before you install the older version of the app, you'll want to uninstall the app completely. You may want to take note of what version the app is currently so you can install the previous version. To uninstall any app: Open Settings app. Tap Apps Tap the app. Tap Force Stop . Tap Uninstall .

steps.title: Enable apps from unknown sources.
steps.content: Enable apps from unknown sources. In order to install an older version of an app, you must allow your phone to install apps from unknown sources. Use the following steps to allow apps from unknown sources: Open Settings app. Tap Lock screen and security . Tap the toggle switch next to "Unknown sources".

steps.title: Open https://www.apkmirror.com in a web browser.
steps.content: Open https://www.apkmirror.com in a web browser. Open your mobile browser and go to the official APK Mirror website.

steps.title: Tap the magnifying glass icon enter the name of the app.
steps.content: Tap the magnifying glass icon enter the name of the app. It's in the upper-right corner of the page. APK Mirror has a lot of current and older versions of many popular apps so look for the version you want to download. If you don't see the specific version you're looking for: Tap the Apps tab. Tap the app's title . Scroll down to All versions (listed newest to oldest).

steps.title: Tap next to the version you want to download.
steps.content: Tap next to the version you want to download. Tap the down-arrow icon on the right, next to the version of the app you want to download. This will take you to the download page.

steps.title: Tap SEE AVAILABLE APKS and tap the variant number of the version that fits your phone.
steps.content: Tap SEE AVAILABLE APKS and tap the variant number of the version that fits your phone. In the "Download" section, under the "Variant" column, tap the version that meets the specifications you noted earlier for your phone. If the version says "arm" then that's the 32-bit version, whereas "arm64" is the 64-bit version. If your phone is 64-bits, you can run 32-bit apps without any problems as long as they are the same type (ARM vs. x86), but a 32-bit phone will not run 64-bit apps. If there is no version that matches your DPI exactly, select the "nodpi" version, as that usually will fit all screen sizes.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap DOWNLOAD APK.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap DOWNLOAD APK . It's a button towards the bottom of the screen. Once the file downloads, you will be asked to open the folder or open the file. It's more effective to open the file in the My Files app. Tap OK if prompted with a disclaimer asking if you want to download this type of file.

steps.title: Open your downloads folder and tap the app your just downloaded.
steps.content: Open your downloads folder and tap the app your just downloaded. On many Android phones, this may be the "Downloads" app in your app drawer, or you might access downloads by tapping the "Files" or "My Files" app and then tapping the "Downloads" folder. Located the APK file you downloaded and tap it.

steps.title: Tap Install.
steps.content: Tap Install . It's in the lower-right corner of the installation screen. This will install the app. After the app installs, it will launch. The first time the app launches, it will ask to access different features on your phone. Tap "Allow" to let the app access the feature it is requesting.
